A block of mass <math alttext="2.0 kilograms " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2.0</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is attached to a light string that is wrapped around a solid cylinder, as shown in the figure. The cylinder has a mass of <math alttext="M equals 2.5 kilograms " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>M</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>2.5</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>kg</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and a radius of <math alttext="R equals 0.40 meter" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>R</mi><mo>=</mo><mn>0.40</mn><mspace depth="0.0ex" height="0.0ex" width="0.3em"></mspace><mtext>m</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> . The cylinder can rotate with negligible friction about a light rod through its central axis. The block-cylinder system is initially held at rest. (a) Using integral calculus, show that the rotational inertia of the cylinder about its central axis is <math alttext="one half times M R squared " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mfrac><mrow><mn>1</mn></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></mfrac><mi>M</mi><msup><mrow><mi>R</mi></mrow><mrow><mn>2</mn></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math>.
(b) The block is released from rest and the string unwinds, causing the cylinder to rotate on the rod.i. Calculate the linear acceleration of the block.
ii. Calculate the net torque exerted on the cylinder.
iii. Calculate the tension in the string.

At time <math alttext="t sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , the block reaches its lowest point as the string has completely unwound. The string then begins to rewind on the cylinder, and the mass is raised back upward. (c) On the axis below, sketch the angular momentum <math alttext="L" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>L</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> of the cylinder as a function of time <math alttext="t " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> from the moment the mass is released to shortly after <math alttext="t sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> .

The solid cylinder is replaced by a hollow cylinder with the same mass and radius. Lightweight spokes attach the hollow cylinder to a light rod through its central axis. The hollow cylinder can rotate around its central axis with negligible friction. The string is wound around the hollow cylinder so that the block is at the same initial position as before. The block is again released from rest. The time it takes for the string to completely unwind from the hollow cylinder is <math alttext="t sub H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> . (d) Is the time <math alttext="t sub H " overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>H</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> greater than, less than, or equal to the time <math alttext="t sub S" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>t</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>S</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mstyle></math> ? Greater than Less than Equal to Justify your answer.
